title: Should the UK leave the European Union?

context.content: The UK has been a member of the European Union and its predecessor bodies since 1973,
with continued membership of the "Common Market" confirmed by a 1975 Referendum.
Since then there has been consensus in favour of continued membership across the major parties,
and no nationwide vote on changes which have increased the role of the EU across a range of formerly domestic policy areas.
However the UK Independence Party, which campaigns for UK withdrawal from the EU, has seen notable political successes,
gaining 16.5% of the vote  in the 2009 European Parliament Elections, and placing second in those elections,
and a notional national share of 23%  of the vote in the 2013 English local government elections.
Following this, the Prime Minister, David Cameron, supported moves to provide for a referendum after the 2015 election,
and there is speculation that Ed Miliband, Leader of the Labour Party, may match this pledge or go further.

noes.title: British laws should be made by British voters

body.content: The European Union represents a declining share of the global economy, from 26% in 1980, to 22% in 2003, and a forecast 17% in 2015.

The European Union limits the UK's ability to take advantage of growth elsewhere in the world, both by acting as a joint negotiator in trade deals so that the UK cannot advance its own interest, and through the imposition of a Common External Tariff - a tax barrier to trade with the rest of the world.

body.content: Estimates for the proportion of laws in EU member states which originate with the EU vary from 6% to 84%.
What is not in doubt is that across a range of issues of intense salience to British voters, from immigration laws
to NHS privatisation, the EU's influence radically limits the ability of national politicians to meet the aspirations of British voters.
